item.title: Could this be a parody? The Advocate-General's viewpoint on the Deckmyn case.
item.description:
Sabine Jacques, a PhD student at the University of Nottingham’s School of Law specializing in parody exceptions, discusses the Advocate-General’s (AG) opinion on the Deckmyn case. The case grapples with the interpretation of copyright exceptions for parodies within EU law, specifically Article 5(3)(k) of the Infosoc Directive, which permits member states to allow exceptions for caricature, parody, or pastiche. Jacques highlights the timely relevance of the opinion, given the ongoing debate over copyright exceptions and the delayed implementation of a parody exception in the UK...

item.title: We have the freedom to laugh at anything, but not everyone can appreciate it!" Examining the boundaries of freedom of expression through parody: the ruling of the CJEU in the Deckmyn case.
item.description:

item.title: Is the REDA report a significant step forward for the parody exception in EU copyright law?
item.description:
By Sabine Jacques In the middle of January, Pirate Party Member of European Parliament, Julia Reda, shared a draft of her report examining the implementation of the Information Society Directive 2001/29/EC (often called the ‘InfoSoc Directive’). This report has been praised by some as groundbreaking for its progressive stance on copyright in the digital age, while others have criticized it as being too radical or even unacceptable. These strong reactions highlight the widespread interest in the report and its potential impact, particularly within digital rights communities...

item.title: The ECJ clarifies EU's authority over copyright law in the Marrakesh Treaty ruling.
item.description:
Gesa Kübek, PhD candidate at the law faculty of the University of Passau. In its February 14, 2017 Opinion 3/15, the European Court of Justice (ECJ) determined that the European Union (EU) possesses exclusive competence to enter into the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works for Persons Who Are Blind, Visually Impaired, or Otherwise Print Disabled (hereafter: Marrakesh Treaty). This decision aligns with Advocate General (AG) Wahl’s prior Opinion, which similarly argued for exclusive EU competence in this domain...
